subject: RE: [junit] Re: Change generic signature of assert that
msgSnippet: Yme, NUnit has a nice implementation of these sort of matchers that works pretty seamlessly-which might imply that .NET handles these typing issues better than
messageBody:
Yme,



NUnit has a nice implementation of these sort of matchers that works
pretty seamlessly-which might imply that .NET handles these typing
issues better than Java. I can't remember running into any situations
like what you are describing. I have run into a few scenarios like
yours involving lists, but, if I remember correctly, those errors had
more to do with an interesting design choice that Microsoft had made
rather than with anything to do in NUnit itself. I'm not familiar
enough with the NUnit source code so I am not sure if any .NET magic was
required to build NUnit or if it was a rather straightforward
implementation.



Rocco



From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
yme0987654321
Sent: Friday, May 22, 2009 3:36 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Re: Change generic signature of assert that








I'm curious if you know of a language that does do such things well. It
seems like the popular ones are moving away from compiler-level type
safety all together.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com> , David
Saff <david@...> wrote:
>
> That much is true. I think that in the end, we'll probably be forced
> back to the untyped version. It was a good dream, but Java just
> really isn't functional enough to pretend to do functional things with
> it.
>
> David Saff
>
> On Fri, May 22, 2009 at 2:48 PM, yme0987654321 <yme0987654321@...>
wrote:
> > I'm also curious the motivation for using generics on the
assertThat. It seems the only thing it gains is that the parameter to
the matcher is the right type for the comparison, but the actual
underlying matches method does not look at the generic, so if it wasn't
the right type and generics were not used, the assert would just fail?
I'm I reading that right?
> >
> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com> ,
"yme0987654321" <yme0987654321@> wrote:
> >>
> >> hasEntry is part of the Hamcrest library. Here is the signature:
> >>
> >> public static <K, V> org.hamcrest.Matcher<java.util.Map<K, V>>
hasEntry(K key, V value)
> >>
> >> I'm curious if you know of a reason that
> >>
> >> public static <T> void assertThat(T actual, Matcher<? extends T>
matcher)
> >>
> >> is wrong. Does it break something that you know of?
> >>
> >>
> >> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com> ,
David Saff <david@> wrote:
> >> >
> >> > On Fri, May 22, 2009 at 1:18 PM, yme0987654321 <yme0987654321@>
wrote:
> >> > > Consider the following case:
> >> > >
> >> > > Map<String, Class<? extends Serializable>> result = null;
> >> > >
> >> > > assertThat(result, hasEntry("Key", java.util.Date.class));
> >> > >
> >> > > This will not compile, but if the method signature of
assertThat was changed to:
> >> > >
> >> > > public static <T> void assertThat(T actual, Matcher<? extends
T> matcher)
> >> > >
> >> > > It would compile.
> >> > >
> >> > > I would seem that it would be an appropriate change for such
cases (unless there is something I don't understand about the deep
implications of Generics).
> >> >
> >> > Sigh.
> >> >
> >> > Unfortunately, it was all too easy for the hamcrest team, a
couple
> >> > months ago, to come up with a list of 6 or 7 assertThat
statements
> >> > that all looked like they should obviously compile or not
compile, but
> >> > no Java typing that would make them all work. It does get deep,
and
> >> > in some cases, compiler-dependent, if I remember correctly.
> >> >
> >> > However, we did find that in some cases, the signature of the
> >> > _Matcher_ could be improved. What's the signature of hasEntry?
> >> >
> >> > This is also pushing me to keep on my "Dotmesh" project, which
would allow this:
> >> >
> >> > assertThat(result.entrySet()).contains(entry("Key", Date.class));
> >> >
> >> > [if the "entry" factory convenience method were written]
> >> >
> >> > Thanks,
> >> >
> >> > David Saff
